events.originalText: A tornado struck Moore, Oklahoma, United States, killing 24 people and causing an estimated $2 billion of damage.
events.subtitle: 2013 Moore tornado
events.headline: Tornado in Moore, Oklahoma Kills 24

events.originalText: The first of two major earthquakes struck Northern Italy, resulting in seven deaths.
events.subtitle: 2012 Northern Italy earthquakes
events.headline: First Major Earthquake Hits Northern Italy, 7 Dead

events.originalText: In deciding Romer v. Evans, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a constitutional amendment in Colorado that prevented protected status under the law for homosexuals or bisexuals.
events.subtitle: Romer v. Evans
events.headline: U.S. Supreme Court Strikes Down Colorado Amendment on Homosexual Rights

events.originalText: uMkhonto we Sizwe, the paramilitary wing of the African National Congress, detonated a car bomb in Pretoria, resulting in 19 deaths and 217.
events.subtitle: UMkhonto we Sizwe
events.headline: Car Bomb in Pretoria Kills 19

events.originalText: While attempting to land at Cairo International Airport, Pakistan International Airlines Flight 705 crashed for unknown reasons, killing all but 6 of the 121 people on board.
events.subtitle: Cairo International Airport
events.headline: Pakistan International Airlines Flight 705 Crashes Near Cairo, 115 Dead

events.originalText: The first session of the National Diet opened in Tokyo, Japan.
events.subtitle: National Diet
events.headline: National Diet Opens in Tokyo, Japan

events.originalText: The Luttra Woman (skull pictured), a bog body from the Early Neolithic period, was discovered near Luttra, Sweden.
events.subtitle: Luttra Woman
events.headline: Bog Body Discovered in Luttra, Sweden

events.originalText: World War II: German paratroopers began the Battle of Heraklion on the island of Crete, capturing the airfield and port in Heraklion ten days later.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: German Paratroopers Begin Battle of Heraklion in Crete

events.originalText: By the Treaty of Jeddah, the United Kingdom recognized the sovereignty of King Abdulaziz of Saudi Arabia (pictured) over Hejaz and Nejd, which later merged to become Saudi Arabia.
events.subtitle: Treaty of Jeddah (1927)
events.headline: Treaty of Jeddah Recognizes King Abdulaziz's Sovereignty Over Hejaz and Nejd

events.originalText: Representatives from seventeen countries signed the Metre Convention, which set up an institute for the purpose of coordinating international metrology and for coordinating the development of the metric system.
events.subtitle: Metre Convention
events.headline: Metre Convention Signed by Seventeen Countries

events.originalText: A British squadron under Charles Marsh Schomberg defeated a French force off Tamatave, Madagascar, that was attempting to reinforce the French garrison on Mauritius.
events.subtitle: Charles Marsh Schomberg
events.headline: British Squadron Defeats French Force off Tamatave, Madagascar

events.originalText: Thomas Thorpe published the first copies of Shakespeare's sonnets, possibly without William Shakespeare's consent.
events.subtitle: Thomas Thorpe
events.headline: Shakespeare's Sonnets Published by Thomas Thorpe

events.originalText: According to the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle, King Æthelberht II of East Anglia was beheaded on the orders of King Offa of Mercia.
events.subtitle: Anglo-Saxon Chronicle
events.headline: King Æthelberht II of East Anglia Beheaded by King Offa of Mercia

events.originalText: The Picts defeated the Northumbrians at the Battle of Dun Nechtain, severely weakening the latter's power in northern Great Britain.
events.subtitle: Picts
events.headline: Picts Defeat Northumbrians at Battle of Dun Nechtain
